Beginning with discussion of various perspectives on social change and law, this course then examines in detail the interdependent relationship between changes in legal and societal institutions. Emphasis will be placed on (1) how and when law can be an instrument for social change, and (2) how and when social change can cause legal change. In the assessment of this relationship, the laws of the United States and other countries as well as international law, will be studied. Throughout the course, discussions will include legal controversies relevant to social change such as civil liberties, gender and the law, and issues of State-Building. A comparative framework will be used in the analysis of this interdependent relationship between law and social change.
 
For the most part, students found this course to be extremely “interesting and engaging” and very “fun to attend.” Several students remarked upon the organization of the class however, stating that the material was convoluted and hard at times to understand, seeming like you had to go into the class with some knowledge about the topic. Students also said that discussions in the class were hard to facilitate, as the structure of the course allows for little outside opinion.
	 
Some students referred to Professor Fetni as “the best they’ve had at Penn” and said they would “take any course he taught.” Others however, commented on his obvious liberal viewpoints that “clearly bias the lectures.” They stated it was hard to have opinions that differ from the professors. Some students found this “refreshing” while others worried it “clouded judgment.” Overall, students generally agreed Professor Fetni was stimulating in his lectures.
 
Students said that this course was difficult and required a lot of work, but it was worth it if you put in the effort. Some students expressed a desire for a prerequisite for the course, but that the readings for “informative.”
